properties.Name: Venus de Milo
properties.About: The Venus de Milo is a famous ancient Greek statue believed to depict the Greek goddess Aphrodite, who was known as Venus to the Romans. It is made of marble and was created sometime between 130 and 100 BCE. The statue is notable for its missing arms, which were likely holding objects such as a shield or an apple. It was discovered in 1820 on the island of Milos in Greece by a farmer when digging in his field. The Venus de Milo is considered a masterpiece of ancient Greek sculpture and is admired for its graceful and idealized depiction of the female form.

properties.Name: Nike of Samothrace (The Winged Victory)
properties.About: The Winged Victory of Samothrace, also known as Nike of Samothrace, is an ancient Greek statue believed to have been created in the 2nd century BCE to commemorate a naval victory. It is made of marble and depicts the Greek goddess Nike, who was known as Victory to the Romans, standing atop the prow of a ship with her wings spread and billowing clothing, as if she has just alighted on the ship. The statue is notable for its dynamic and lifelike depiction of movement and is admired for its sense of triumph and power. It was discovered in 1863 on the island of Samothrace in Greece by French diplomat Charles Champoiseau. The Winged Victory of Samothrace is considered one of the greatest masterpieces of ancient Greek sculpture.

properties.Name: Zeus and Ganymede
properties.About: The statue of Zeus and Ganymede depicts the Greek god Zeus, king of the gods, and Ganymede, a young Trojan prince whom Zeus abducted and made his cupbearer in Greek mythology. It is believed to have been created during the Hellenistic period, sometime between the 2nd century BCE and the 2nd century CE. The statue shows Zeus seated on a throne and holding Ganymede in his arms, with Ganymede's arm around Zeus's neck. The statue is notable for its sensual and intimate depiction of the two figures, and for its depiction of the mythological theme of homoeroticism, which was common in ancient Greek culture. The first parts were found at the archaeological site of Olympia in 1878, and further pieces were found in the same location in 1938.

properties.Name: The Artemision Bronze
properties.About: The Artemision Bronze is an ancient Greek bronze statue of either Zeus or Poseidon that was discovered from a Roman shipwreck off the coast of Cape Artemision, Greece in 1928. It is believed to date back to the 5th century BCE and is notable for its advanced level of naturalistic detail, such as the intricate musculature and facial features of the figure. The statue depicts a nude male figure standing with his weight on one leg, his other leg slightly bent, and his arms outstretched. It is unclear whether the statue depicts Zeus or Poseidon, but it is thought to have been created to commemorate a military victory or as a votive offering in a sanctuary. The Artemision Bronze is considered one of the finest examples of ancient Greek bronze sculpture.

properties.Name: The Parthenon Marbles
properties.About: The Parthenon Marbles, also known as the Elgin Marbles, are a collection of ancient Greek marble sculptures that originally decorated the Parthenon temple in Athens, Greece. They were created during the 5th century BCE by the famous Greek sculptor Phidias and depict various figures from Greek mythology, including the goddess Athena, gods and goddesses, and mythical creatures. In the early 19th century, a British nobleman named Lord Elgin removed a large portion of the sculptures from the Parthenon and brought them to Britain. The removal of the sculptures has been a source of controversy and debate for many years, with Greece calling for their return to Athens. The Parthenon Marbles are considered some of the finest examples of ancient Greek sculpture and are admired for their exquisite detail and beauty.

properties.Name: Hermes and the Infant Dionysus
properties.About: The statue of Hermes and the Infant Dionysus is an ancient Greek sculpture believed to have been created in the 4th century BCE. It depicts the Greek god Hermes, who was known as the messenger of the gods and the patron of travelers, holding the infant Dionysus, the god of wine and fertility, in his arms. The sculpture is notable for its delicate and naturalistic portrayal of the two figures, with Hermes's gentle expression and Dionysus's relaxed pose. The statue is believed to have been created as a votive offering or to commemorate a mythological event, and it is admired for its technical mastery and beauty. An earthquake resulted in the collapse of the Temple of Hera, burying this statue in rubble until it was discovered in 1877 among the ruins.

properties.Name: The Altar of Pergamon
properties.About: The Altar of Pergamon is an ancient Greek monument that was built in the 2nd century BCE in the ancient city of Pergamon, located in present-day Turkey. It is a massive structure, measuring over 35 meters wide and 33 meters deep, and was created to commemorate the victories of the Attalid dynasty in battles against the Gauls. The altar is decorated with elaborate reliefs that depict scenes from Greek mythology, including the Gigantomachy, a mythological battle between the gods and the giants. The reliefs are notable for their dramatic and dynamic portrayal of the figures, with intricate details and emotive expressions. The Altar of Pergamon is considered one of the greatest masterpieces of Hellenistic art.

properties.Name: The Lady of Auxerre
properties.About: The Lady of Auxerre is an ancient Greek limestone statue believed to have been created during the 7th century BCE in the town of Auxerre in France. The statue depicts a female figure who is believed to be a goddess, although her identity is uncertain. She is standing with her feet together and her arms at her sides, and is wearing a long, flowing garment that covers her body. Her hair is pulled back in a style typical of ancient Greek art, and she has a serene expression on her face. The statue is notable for its simplicity and elegance, and for its representation of the early stages of ancient Greek sculpture. Interestingly enough, this statue was discovered in a storage vault in the town of Auxerre, Paris in 1907. There is no information behind how or why this statue ended up in that vault.

properties.Name: The Kritios Boy
properties.About: The Kritios Boy is an ancient Greek marble statue believed to have been created during the Late Archaic period, around 480 BCE. The statue is named after its creator, the Greek sculptor Kritios, and is considered one of the earliest examples of the Classical style of ancient Greek sculpture. The statue depicts a young male figure standing with his weight on one leg, his other leg slightly bent, and his arms at his sides. The figure's head is turned slightly to the side, and his hair is arranged in a style typical of ancient Greek art. It was discovered in 1866 in the Acropolis of Athens, the head was later found in 1889 at the same spot. The Kritios Boy is notable for its realism and naturalism, with the figure's musculature and facial features depicted in exquisite detail.

properties.Name: The Dying Warrior
properties.About: The Dying Warrior is an ancient Greek sculpture believed to have been created in the 5th century BCE. The sculpture is part of a larger work known as the East Pediment of the Temple of Aphaia on the Greek island of Aegina. The East Pediment depicts the mythological story of the Trojan War, and the Dying Warrior is one of the figures represented. The sculpture portrays a wounded warrior, with his head resting on his shield and his arm draped over his face. His body is contorted in pain, and his expression is one of agony. The figure is depicted with great realism and emotional depth, with the artist capturing the physical and emotional suffering of the dying warrior.

properties.Name: The Charioteer of Delphi
properties.About: The Charioteer of Delphi is an ancient Greek bronze sculpture that is believed to have been created in the 5th century BCE. The statue was discovered in 1896 in the Sanctuary of Apollo in Delphi, Greece, and is considered one of the finest examples of ancient Greek sculpture. The statue depicts a charioteer wearing a long robe and holding the reins of his chariot in his left hand. His right hand is extended as if he is reaching for a prize, and his expression is one of intense concentration. The statue is notable for its lifelike portrayal of the charioteer, with intricate details such as the texture of his hair and the folds of his robe. It is believed that the statue was created to commemorate the victory of a charioteer in one of the ancient Greek games.

properties.Name: The Riace Bronzes
properties.About: The Riace Bronzes are a pair of ancient Greek bronze statues discovered in 1972 by a diver off the coast of Riace, Italy. The statues are believed to have been created in the 5th century BCE and depict two nude male figures, one slightly larger than the other. The figures are depicted in a lifelike pose, with intricate details such as bulging muscles and veins. One of the figures is believed to represent a warrior, while the other is believed to represent an athlete. The Riace Bronzes are considered some of the finest examples of ancient Greek bronze sculpture, and their discovery was a significant event in the world of art and archaeology.

properties.Name: The Marble Metopes of the Parthenon
properties.About: The Marble Metopes of the Parthenon are a set of ancient Greek sculptures that adorned the exterior of the Parthenon temple in Athens, Greece. The metopes are rectangular panels carved from marble, each depicting a scene from Greek mythology or history. The metopes were created in the mid-5th century BCE, and many of them have survived to this day despite damage over the centuries. The metopes depict a wide range of subjects, including battles between humans and mythical creatures, such as centaurs and Amazons, as well as scenes from Greek mythology, such as the Labors of Hercules. The Metopes are considered to be some of the finest examples of ancient Greek relief sculpture.

properties.Name: The Sacred Gate Dipylon Kouros
properties.About: The Sacred Gate Dipylon Kouros is an ancient Greek sculpture believed to have been created in the late 8th century BCE. The statue was discovered in 1863 at the Dipylon cemetery, located outside the gates of Athens, Greece. The Kouros is a male figure standing upright, with his arms at his sides and his left leg slightly advanced. The figure's body is rigidly frontal, with the head and eyes looking straight ahead. The statue is notable for its size, standing at over six feet tall, and for its intricate details, including the elaborate hair and musculature. The Dipylon Kouros is considered one of the earliest examples of the Kouros type of ancient Greek sculpture, which was popular during the Archaic period.

properties.Name: Kleobis & Biton
properties.About: The Kleobis and Biton statue is an ancient Greek sculpture that depicts two young men from the town of Argos. The statue was created in the 6th century BCE and is believed to have been dedicated at the Temple of Hera in Olympia, Greece. The statue depicts the two brothers standing side by side, with their arms at their sides and their legs together. The figures are depicted in a stylized manner, with idealized muscular bodies and serene expressions. The statue is notable for its historical and cultural significance, as the story of Kleobis and Biton was well known in ancient Greece. According to legend, the brothers pulled their mother's cart to a religious festival, showing their devotion and strength. The goddess Hera was so impressed by their piety that she granted them the gift of a peaceful death.
